title: Opening

author: Toby Walsh, NICTA, Australia's ICT Research Centre of Excellence

segmentation: Welcome, it's it's wonderful to see all of you here.
I'm the very first international conference I ever published in and attended.
Was each kind 1989 in Detroit and it's great privilege and an honor, therefore, to be program chair of this is this.
Great conference and I never expected back then I'd be standing up here talking to you now.
So I just want to give you a quick taste tap pass of some of the things that we've got planned for you in the next three or four days.
There are, there are two very interesting keynote talks both cover aspects of the smarter Web by Wendy Hall tomorrow Morning and Susan Athey on Wednesday morning.
And there's a large number.
Six other invited talks that I encourage you to go to.
I very carefully not programmed not scheduled anything at all against the invited talks so that all of you can appreciate the many interesting things that will be mentioned then.
As was mentioned earlier, a new innovation we have running throughout the length of the conference.
We have a track of 49 best papers taken from a wide selection of sister related conferences that I invited.
The program and conference chairs to select and to present to help, perhaps try and bring back parts of the community that otherwise might splinter often.
So give you a little taste of some of the very best work that's going on in the various subfields of artificial intelligence.
I've also taken advantage of that track to to allow the best papers that you just heard being awarded the J.

Each guy best paper prize from this year and also from from last year to be presented and finally another hat I wear is the chair of the Echo Best Thesis Award Committee and as has been the tradition for a number of years now.
We also have a presentation from the best thesis which is again.
Both the gerund, each type papers, and the best.
This is the best.
These papers are presented tomorrow morning in the best paper track.
Just a brief word about the submissions.
We I was inundated with submissions.
We had a record number of submissions.
13125 papers were eventually sent out for review from 59 countries that again, that was that was a local record as well, and from those we had a very careful selection process.
We had selected 227 papers that will be presented both as as talks and as posters and.
Further, 170 three that will present it just as posters, so that's around total of 400 exactly.
If you want to hear some more detailed statistics, do get up early tomorrow morning.
I'll tell you the breakdown by country.
You can see how how well Spain did.
I'll do a detailed breakdown also bye bye area as well.
We selected three distinguished papers, and those were both the price for those will be given out tomorrow morning.

So again, I'd like you to encourage you to come along to see the prize being given out and those presentations that also will happen immediately tomorrow following in the morning following the the keynote talk.
As was mentioned earlier, we had a special track, a special theme I wanted to encourage people who who build large AI systems bring all the components that we may work on individually.
So to try and encourage that we have, we had a special track.

I thank the chair special track with that attracted nearly hundred submissions and you'll see in one of the parallel tracks, large number of interesting papers talking about the hard work of integrating and.
AI and embedding it in real world systems.

There's also I encourage you to to to to attend the industry day on Friday we've got a large number of invited talks from from some very interesting people in Microsoft, Google, Telefonica, Yahoo, and various other companies telling us about about using AI and industry.
A lot of talks about data mining, machine learning that I think will be in jeopardy.
That will be very interesting, and I thank the Industry Day chair for all their hard work in putting that tracked again.
We've also revived the video track that's happened in a number of past.
Each guys Anna thank Peter Stone for putting that track together, there's.
19 videos are going to be screened continuously in a in a room in the Conference Center throughout the conference that you can you get to see them.
There is a price that we hope to give at the end of the conference.
The farewell event, and if you look carefully in your registration back in the envelope, I think there was a little voting slip with the four finalists for the best video.
And I encourage you to go and watch the videos and select what you think is the best video and vote its approval voting.
I thought very carefully about.
How best to do this so it's approval voting?
You get to vote for as many as you like and the winner will be announced on Friday afternoon at the farewell event.
And there will be a special part of the best paper track tomorrow morning while screen those ones, especially so if you want to go along to capture those ones at that time, I encourage you to do.
Amps.
I ran on Lou is a famous 13th century Catalan local philosopher and scholar and we thought it was quite appropriate and nice to to celebrate an honor his his contributions.
Many people actually would consider him to be one of the fathers of computational science of artificial intelligence.
He you thought about logical reasoning before many other people did.
He was a very major influence on on on.
On Leibnitz, and so if you want to discover more, there are a number of ways you can do that.
There's a special part of the scientific program.
on Thursday afternoon, we have two invited keynotes for some leading scholars in the area, and a panel talking about his contributions to two social choice and to voting and computer science.
So you can go along to that.
There's also thank very much Carla Sarah, who's put together, edited.
A book that survived that's actually in your in your registration back.
A very nice booklets covering some papers that talk about his contributions.
If you're worried by the way, if you're worried that there's so many things going on, there are so many things going on, we have frayed a parallel tracks.
I've tried to schedule things as carefully as I can can to reduce conflict so you know, I used some of my scheduling know how to do that, but they will appreciate.
Be some conflicts.
Don't worry every talk.
In the conference is being videoed and being put up on the web so you can sit back during your summer vacation and enjoy some of the things that you may have missed.
One of the things that I think is very important I appreciated this back in 89 when I was a PhD student attending.
Each guy is to is to continue to grow the community and it was very important to me that we look to ways at at growing the community and encouraging student participation.
So I'm very pleased and very very thankful to to the I don't know who put up $50,000 in travel grants, most of which almost all of which went to the PhD students participating in here.
And each guy itself that contributed another $50,000.
That's why I'm supporting 139 participants from from 2029 different countries and we also had a very large contribution from the NSF.

The Doc Tauriel consortium that I attended this morning this morning and gave her presentation out they got $45,000 from NSF to again encourage participation and $1800 from Google, so I thank all of those organisations.
I welcome all the students, maybe one day you will be standing here so.

It's very nice to have you here and to have you contributing and to help their students to get networking and to meet other people I know is very intimidating amongst the other thousands and more people than reach guide 89 to to meet people.

We've organized reception for you on Thursday evening and so please go along to that and meet some other people and as far as funny as I mentioned, there was a a doctoral consortium error that was running today.
I was.
Able to attend part of that and the focus of that actually was interesting.
Leon on discussion and talk about ethics, and I hope that was useful to the students and and I was, I thank the chairs for putting all that together and all the hard work they did their thing.
There are a number of other events are going to go through this very quickly and you will see them going going on in the exhibition space and elsewhere.
We have the final of the trading agent competition that's happening tomorrow and then on Wednesday, Thursday we have the final of the general game playing competition.
Another event that I think may be interesting to many of you is that we've got a panel on Wednesday evening on funding opportunities for international collaboration.
We've got representatives from.
And in fact, the European Commission, the Usair Force, and Nick to presenting the Australian perspective.
So you're encouraged to go along and find out some opportunities there.
There are a lot of social events.
We were we wanted this to be an inclusive conference.
As mentioned, they're all included in your registration fee.
The banquet.
I'm sure it's going to be another special event, like tonight.
I mentioned already the student reception and I encourage you to stay around to the very end without carefully scheduled the final invited talk at the end.
It's a very interesting talk from Jonathan Schaefer on on on playing games with computers.
Sure, he's a great speaker.
Will be very entertaining talk and after that there's more food and drink.
I mean, we're raffling lots and lots of things away.
We're wrapping up a couple of iPads.
There's some netbooks that we were using for the presentations.
There's books that the publishers have donated lots of other things to enter the raffle.
Do you just have to put your your registration badge in the urn at the back of the room at the start of the raffle?
So please, if you if your travel arrangements allow it, stay around to the end.
We're going to have lots of drink and Carver.
I'm sure it's going to be a fun way to say goodbye and to wish you a safe return.
And to look forward to Beijing 2030.
I just want to quickly end with a.
Now this is where I wanted all the authors to pay attention to please.
I had a couple of people asked me today.
Your talks are exactly 20 minutes long.
That means you speak for just 17 minutes to allow the three minutes for questions.
I know it's quite brief, but we have a very packed program and I wanted to reduce the parallelism as much as I could.
You do also get to present as a poster, so you've got plenty of opportunities there.
Please arrive early, introduce yourself to the chair.

And please use the opportunity when the author in front of you is answering questions to set up the computer world or to do whatever you need to get your Ivy working so that we can seamlessly hand over.
And I appreciate your your understanding with that everyones got who's got a poster.
Please do get the posters set up in advance so that they are there in advance of the beginning of the poster session.
Thank you.
I have many people to end by thanking being a program chair is bit of a job.
As a conductor.
You're conducting a large effort from many other people and I would like to thank all those people.
But there are far too many to name I'm afraid.
In person, my 32 area chairs the 400, we 426 senior PC members at the 1000 plus PC members would like to thank very much also all the authors.
The more than 4000.
Plus, authors have submitted papers you.
It was a great responsibility that you are interested in in myself and the rest of the organization with your papers and I we tried our hardest to do your best.
Sam
There is a physical way I have thanking the PC and that the SBC I got my organization Nick to to donate some money to towards a best PC and SBC award.
It's an iPad for the best PC and an iPad for the best.
These SPC and that Ward will be announced and presented tomorrow morning at 8:30 in the opening event.
So I congratulate the three finalists in each case that it was a very tough.
Award to disid and many, many other deserved deserving people.
I think these 3 three sets of two sets of people who stood out especially I mean.
As I said, we will be giving the prize out tomorrow.
Ham I have a very special thanks for my wife and daughter.
They excuse me.
They they gave me the time to put together the technical program and that was a great gift.
They gave me to you.
And I just want to end by thanking you all and for the Spanish people, a little afraid.
I'm not a great linguist and my voice is going as well.
Let US colleges students is espera cast of, enter or say our progress closer an for the Catalans gracias por la Vostra hospitality on our quest a quitter maravillosa.
OK, thank you Toby.
Next we have the world premiere of the opera Casper oh composed by Luc Steels with a libretto by Oscar Villa Roya.
Following up, we're going to have food and drink downstairs in the opera is going to start shortly, so please remain in your seats while we set up the stage.

And one thing I would like to mention is that the opera is going to be professionally recorded, so I would ask you all to take out your cell phones now and turn them off or at least turn them so there to vibrate mode.
I now declare its guy 2011 to be open.
Thank you.
